segments.text: Good God.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Do you think it's them?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I wonder.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: And nobody knows we're here except for Freda and she wouldn't ring up.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well it must be them then.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What are you going to do?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: We're fine right?  Aren't we?  Whatever happens darling.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Now and always sweet.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't care then.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I mean, it was, it's bound to come out sooner or later.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Hello?  Hello?  What?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: That sent shivers up my spine.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No, wrong number.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What are we to do if they suddenly walk in on us?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Behave exquisitely.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: With the most perfect poise?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Certainly.  And I shall probably do a court courtesy.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: um- Things that should matter dreadfully don't seem to matter at all when one's happy do they?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What is so horrible is that one cannot stay happy.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Oh, darling.  Don't say that.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It's true.  I mean, the whole business it's a very poor joke.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You mean that, that sacred and beautiful thing love?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yes.  I mean just that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: What does that all mean?  That's what I asked myself on my quest for ultimate truth.  What does it all mean?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Don't laugh at me.  I'm serious.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: [LAUGHTER] Oh, darling.  You mustn't be serious, that's just what they want.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Who's they?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: All the futile moralists who try to make life unbearable.  Laugh at them.  Be flippant.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Laugh at all their sacred shibboleths.  Flippancy brings the acid in their damn sweetness and light.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: So if I'm to laugh at everything then I must laugh at us too.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Oh, certainly, you must.  We're figures of fun alright.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: How long will it last?  This ludicrous overbearing love of ours?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Who knows?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Shall we always want to bicker and fight?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No.  That fire will fade along with our passion.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, dear, shall we want that?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well, it depends on how well we've played.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What happens if one of us dies?  I mean, does the other one still laugh?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Of course, yes, yes, with all his might.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: That's serious enough.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No.  No it isn't.  That's very laughable, a cunning little mystery all done with mirrors.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Darling I believe you're talking nonsense.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Oh, and who isn't talking nonsense?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Let's be superficial and pity the poor philosophers hmmm?  Let's blow trumpets and squeakers and party as much as we can like quite idiotic school children.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Let's savor the delight of the moment.  Come kiss me darling before worms pop in and out of your eye sockets.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Elliot, worms don't pop.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't care what you do, you see?  As long, no I don't care what you do, see?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You can put green paint all over your body and dance naked in the Place Vendome and rush off madly with all the men in the world and I shan't say a word as long as you love me best.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Thank you dear.  The same applies to you...
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: ...only if you ever so much as look at another woman I'll kill you.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Remember that awful scene we had in Venice?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Which particular one?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: The one when you bought a little painted wooden snake in the Piazza and put it in my bed.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Charles, that was his name, Charles.  Oh, God he was so wiggled so beautifully.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Horrible little thing.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yeah.  I know you did.  You threw it out the window and into the Grand Canal.  I don't think I'll ever forgive you for that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I hated it.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: How long did that rile last?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It went on intermittently for days.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Oh, the worst one was in Cannes when you-
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I burnt a hole in my comb too and all the towels in the bathroom.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: you're curling iron burnt a hole in my dressing gown.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: That was a rouser wasn't it?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: [LAUGHTER] Yeah.  That was the first time you ever hit me.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I didn't hit you very hard.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: The manager came in and saw us rolling on the floor, scratching and biting like panthers.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I will never forget his face. Ooh-rah [LAUGHTER].
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: How ridiculous.  How utterly, utterly ridiculous.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: We were very much younger then.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: And much sillier too.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: The real cause of that rile was Peter Burden.
segments.speaker: M
